title: Tuesday, 27th November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Okay, let's get this over with.

BE11:08am

"This" being Markets Live, FT Alphaville's thing with etc.

Soundbuy Morning

chopper bear morning
Penguin Morning

There's a stupid amount going on today but it's mostly corporate so, frankly, if you want to grumble on about trade tariffs or the inflationary effects of oil breakevens in the Permian basin then you're in the wrong place.

Thomas Cook Group plc (TCG:LSE): Last: 36.84, down 11.7 (-24.11%), High: 39.56, Low: 32.64, Volume: 32.77m

Okay, so this is curious.

BE11:11am

It's a profit warning, obv. Third of the year. But not for the same reason as the other two.

11:12 am

In essence, CEO Peter Fankhauser has had a look at the books two days before FY results were due and decided that what a bunch of stuff previously classed as exceptional will now be underlying.

BE11:12am

"a number of legacy and nonrecurring charges"

Bluesky21 The same CEO Peter Fankhauser who’s been in place since 2014?

As in, a £14m writedown on historic receivables, £4m of flight disruption costs, £10m of further transformation costs ......

TonaldDrump hi hello hi

.... all to be taken through the bottom line.

BE11:14am

BE11:15am

So anyway, most of this is non cash so the shares being down 25% or so might look harsh.

Bluesky21 But CFO Bill Scott is leaving end of November
11:15 am

Until you get to the net debt line.

Bluesky21 Maybe he’s finally taking a stand?
FJ Earnings after cost of revenue? That's rare.

BE11:15am

11:16 am

It's no surprise that winter bookings are poor and the net debt figure is a reflection of that ......

red is tcg in biz of selling holidays to those that can least afford?

.... but it does rather emphasise the crunch point the business faces as it waits for the summer bookings to arrive.

BE11:18am

Hence, the (pretty insignificant in the scheme of things) divi gets suspended too.

Here's Citi.

VV75 morning
BE11:18am

We expect investors will question management on liquidity over the next
few months given the seasonally weak cash position at this time of year.
Management comments that the group’s lenders “remain supportive” and that the group has secured “additional flexibility” but investors will remain concerned about further working capital weakness.

TonaldDrump Cheap as chips in comp to everyone else
BE11:19am

And Barclays.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

This statement does not look good. TCG has released results early as EBIT for FY18 is now £250m rather than the guidance of £280m when TCG released a pre-close profit warning in September (at that time, the new £280m guidance was 13% below Bloomberg consensus EBIT). Not only is this a further downgrade but the company has cut its FY18 dividend too. The reason for the further profit warning is an accounting change that reclassifies certain separately disclosed items (SDIs) into underlying EBIT (£30m). SDIs already look elevated at £153m (nearly a two thirds of underlying EBIT… we note that ‘reported operating profit will be a primary focus going forward’) so if this additional £30m was not reclassified, it implies SDIs would have been £183m. There is no guidance for 2019 (not a surprise given the recent changes in CFO) but TCG seeks to improve the UK tour operator (EBIT down £88m in FY18) and improve capacity management. Additionally, the focus is improving ‘selling higher-margin own-brand hotels and differentiated holidays’ – a strategy that TUI introduced over five years ago and a core strategy for Tour Operators seeking to defend margins in a competitive industry. While the share price has materially underperformed the FTSE 250, by 55% since 1/5/18, we would reiterate our view that while Thomas Cook may appear cheap, it is risky given the poor FCF generation and given the strategy seems to have lagged peers. Current trading looks soft too (bookings for Tour Operator -3% YoY).

BE11:21am

Just reading the conference call ......

BE11:21am

Patrick Coffey of Barclays asks three times for Thomas Cook to detail its covenants ..... and didn't get an answer.

wayneJ Could it be Britons are unsure how expensive summer holidays will be going forward - and will instead stay at home and eat cake?
FATDAZ Re Thomas Cook - yet another example of the inability of management to run a seasonal cyclical business is this a failing of UK managements or is it common to other countries too??
11:22 am

I'm not going to reveal the details of the covenants, but we had 2 covenants that are leveraged and fixed charge coverage. That's the 2 covenants that we have.

Here's a cracking one that comes from [checks notes] ......... Jefferies Equity Research.

NMC Health PLC (NMC:LSE): Last: 3,454, down 146.3 (-4.06%), High: 3,484, Low: 3,252, Volume: 271.59k
11:27 am
BE11:27am

So ............. There are several parts to this.

BE11:27am

The first is that Saudi isn't UAE.

TonaldDrump anyone see yesterday about Liberum being bought up? Is this the way its going to go? All the little guys gobbled up because of mifid?
BE11:28am

More competition, smaller expat community, more government funding of patients, etc. So NMC's Saudi joint venture won't deliver UAE type returns, meaning it's best to value it separately.

FATDAZ Does anyone make money out of travel these days I wonder?
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Then you have to look at the rest of the business. And you begin to notice it's a rollup.

Tom Dalgleish @Wayne, or which other companies are on the precipice to maintain profitability
BE11:29am

NMC continues to raise capital for further M&A but the strategy is increasingly broad while low cash conversion and overdue receivable are called into question.

BE11:30am

Then you look at cash and notice that cashflow from operations excludes interest costs, which is a bit odd.

CrowK Thos Cook share price was 138p the day before Harriet Green was inexplicably ousted
rw42 i'm sure booking.com are doing well - these days usability of the website matters more than brand loyalty which might explain TCG going splat?
FATDAZ @tonals possibly but the whole history of broking in London has been one of acquisition then staff leave form boutiques and grow them again the issue will be will it be possible to start and operate a boutique post this next round of consolidation?
11:30 am
BE11:30am

You also notice that overdue receivables and goodwill have gone sharply higher of late.

FATDAZ @tonald that should say
BE11:31am

And then you look at management's STIP and LTIP schemes and spot that they've dumped EPS as the measure in favour of ebitda.

BE11:31am

Even though net income as a % of EBITDA has declined from 78% to 53% in 2012-17.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

So, you sell. That's the upshot here.

BE11:32am

NMC is a well-loved story. Indeed, attractive healthcare fundamentals in the UAE, expansion of the highly profitable IVF segment, and close ties to the Saudi government ahead of anticipated privatization, all translate into
double-digit-earnings growth on which there is little-to-no tax. While this
sounds appealing and has historically rewarded investors, in this report we revisit some of our concerns which have increased following recent M&A. For some investors, these are adequately compensated for with forecasted EBITDA growth. We, on the other hand, see increasing risks if the company continues on the same path, down which it looks to be accelerating with the recent Aspen and GOSI deals; hence we believe the market is overestimating the value-creation potential. Downgrade to Underperform with a £29.40 PT.

wayneJ The issue is that 'in theory' a travel agency should be a high ROCE co. - but (1) hotels require guarantees to allocate rooms (2) you are subject to currency risk (3) unless you have exclusive product you lack differentiation (4) without differentiation you lack protection in a transparent world ie Bookings.com etc (5) but to get exclusive product you risk your balance sheet every season ---- in essence exactly the same problem that M&S has
BE11:34am

So you have NMC operating 100+ hospitals in 17 countries, while also making nearly all its money from just a handful of them.

wayneJ And this is before we discuss the attached airlines - charters help control your cost and improve your ability to package and differentiation but then you fancy the issue of maintaining load - especially in offseason.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

And doing 18 deals in the past 12 months.

BE11:35am

How do you value that speed of expansion when there looks to be little rhyme or reason to the targets?

FATDAZ @wayne J so its about execution and product lines and hard to be nimble when you are a large vertical player
BE11:35am

Recent transactions in the UK and Saudi have, in our view, raised several issues which are of increasing concern to investors. While some of these have been strategy-related, as with Aspen which gave NMC developed-market presence outside of IVF, a few questions have also been directed towards the structure of the deals and transparency on financials.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

And it's a debt-funded rollup.

BE11:36am

Which doesn't tend to be great news when rates rise.

BE11:36am

Whilst debt levels are manageable (2018E: 2.9x ND/EBITDA; 4.4x interest cover), with higher rates and an inflationary environment we would expect the market to place greater scrutiny on affordability as we estimate greater than 70% of NMC’s debt has a floating rate of interest (greater than 50% post November bond issuance). 3yr avg cash conversion as of 2017 of 55% post interest (39% if also include maintenance capex) place higher reliance on outside capital for growth.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Though Jefferies concedes it may be shouting into the void here.

BE11:37am

For now, a growth-starved investor community might pay little attention to these issues as NMC continues to benefit from the attractive healthcare trends in the Middle East and access to the debt markets which fuel its expansion and feed the earnings momentum. Over time however we would caution against complacency.

BE11:37am

Good note. Recommended.

BE11:41am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:42am

It’s not as though footfall has miraculously been picking out a trip to Greggs and then going straight home (although its newer ranges are resonating with customers), it’s more a case that conversion of potential customers has improved. That is down to better staff training, which has meant that, especially at breakfast time, queue lengths have fallen and that has the happy consequence of reducing the number of customers taking a look at the queue and going elsewhere. To be more specific on range, the Christmas product has landed well, but there has been a strong showing across the piece and of course strong LFL like this has had a positive impact on waste and thus margins. Costs have been firmly marshalled as well (despite the improvement in queue lengths) and that is a function of management’s concern over trading earlier in the year (which now feels like a distant memory), and consequent mitigating cost purge. It’s not all in the bag yet, and the next few weeks remain crucial, but Greggs is sufficiently confident to flag a 6% PBT upgrade from c. £82m to £86.7m for us (£85m becomes £89m next year).

wayneJ And nothing that immediately strikes me as telling me why I should use TCG and what they have that is exclusive to them
A. M. @waynej: at the end of the day, what you get is an interface to sabre/amadeus/whatever-it's-called.
11:42 am
BE11:42am

We have to own up to getting too carried away with the slowdown earlier in the year. Even with the benefit of hindsight management is still at a bit of a loss to explain why the late Spring/early Summer was so weak, but it was clearly no more than a blip and was probably a reaction to the very un-Spring-like weather conditions across Easter. Since then things have picked back up and the performance in the last few weeks, against those tough comps at a time when footfall has generally been weak, is highly impressive. Therefore we have to take our medicine on the recommendation and upgrade back to Hold. At first glance we were tempted to go further, but the valuation at the shares’ current levels doesn’t appear to have much upside. The cash generation however will be highly attractive to some and there are many worse places to be if the top down view is a nervous one.

Despite several setbacks through FY18, UDG has exceeded guided FY18 YoY cc earnings growth outlined initially in January in the range of 18% - 21%, recording growth of 22% vs our estimate of 19%. While a reduction in the US corporate tax rate from 35% to 21% entering the year, and initial contribution from acquisitions in FY17 aided that outcome, confidence in the outlook and momentum for the Group is evident in a reiteration of medium term-growth and a 20% YoY increase in the dividend (16c) vs our estimate of 5% (14c).

And RBC.

BE12:05pm

We are surprised by the scale of negative reaction to UDG’s share price at its FY18 results today. The company has delivered results ahead of expectations on each metric against our and consensus estimates whilst outlining a positive outlook statement. Surmising our view post the results we would note:

1. Management has reiterated its medium-term outlook expectations for double-digit EBIT growth, albeit this will be softened somewhat in FY19E by investment in the growth area of Ashfield (Communications & Advisory) and continued weakness in Commercial & Clinical. However, net, we believe this will lead to no worse outcome than what we have seen in FY18 from an organic growth perspective for either Ashfield or for the Group as a whole (in fact, we think we could see an uptick in organic growth).

2. On Sharp, whilst the EU has been lacklustre given the delay from a major customer, there are reasons to remain positive for a return to growth here, not least from investment in Clinical facilities coming online this year. From speaking with management, we understand that the facilities are being audited by Big Pharma customers (have had over five in recent months), which could lead to a recurring revenue stream above what it already gets from primarily tier two and three customers. We then see serialisation coming into effect in FY19E (Feb), which should, potentially, lead to an influx of customers, just as we saw for the US business.

3. On the bigger, more important, US business of Sharp, the growth rates have been strong and, again from speaking with management, we understand this is due to an influx of customers seeking to be compliant with serialisation changes. We understand this is leading to increased investment in the business with management outlining potential pinch points on capacity in the medium term given the demand levels (and also leading to better pricing).

Whilst the group is set to be low growth in FY19E, a balance of puts and takes in Ashfield against a strong Sharp business, we think this should rebound nicely in FY20E. What’s more, against our own estimates, we actually see forecast risk to the upside in both years before we consider M&A with management having ample resources (c$350m) to make acquisitions within the coming year.
